In an electrostatic field, the electric displacement density vector, $\vec{D}$, is given by $$ \vec{D}(x, y, z)=\left(x^{3} \vec{i}+y^{3} \vec{j}+x y^{2} \vec{k}\right) C / m^{2} $$ where $\overrightarrow{\mathrm{i}}, \overrightarrow{\mathrm{j}}, \overrightarrow{\mathrm{k}}$ are the unit vectors along $\mathrm{x}$-axis, y-axis, and z-axis, respectively. Consider a cubical region $\mathrm{R}$ centered at the origin with each side of length $1 \mathrm{~m}$, and vertices at $( \pm 0.5 \mathrm{~m}, \pm 0.5 \mathrm{~m}, \pm 0.5 \mathrm{~m}$ ). The electric charge enclosed within $R$ is $\qquad$ $\mathrm{C}$ (rounded off to two decimal places).,,"
